newsitem.title: INDIA: High input costs hurt 96/97 net, India ACC says.
newsitem.headline: High input costs hurt 96/97 net, India ACC says.

text.p: India's leading cement firm Associated Cement Companies (ACC) said on Wednesday its post-tax profit for the year ended March 31, 1997 was hit by a steep rise in input costs and a deceleration in cement demand.
"Unprecedented cost increases in the major inputs such as coal, power as well as increase in the cost of transportation exerted considerable pressure on operating margins," it said.
The company said its net profit fell to 769.2 million rupees in 1996/97 from 2.27 billion rupees in the previous year.
ACC said the second half of the year saw an unprecedented downturn in the industry which led to unremunerative prices in most parts of the country.
"Absence of income from sale of investments, the lower dividend income from Unit Trust of India (UTI) and other income also contributed to the reduction in profits," a statement said.
ACC's refractory business was also saw a squeeze on margins during the year, it said.
Cement production in 1996/97 rose to 9.03 million tonnes against 8.93 million tonnes in the previous year. Clinker production rose by 4.1 percent to 7.46 million tonnes.
Cement sales (excluding traded third party cement) rose to 9.05 million tonnes against 8.84 million tonnes.
Sale of traded cement rose to 0.6 million tonnes in 1996/97 from 0.54 milloin tonnes a year ago.
"Similarly, export of cement also showed improvement to touch 0.25 million tonnes from 0.23 million tonnes last year," the statement concluded.
